header.title: StereoTypes Paris - French African vs. African American?
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: What's it like to be a black person in France? What's the immigrant experience for people of African descent? StereoTypes host Ryan Hall hits the streets of Paris to find out. Watch more StereoTypes here: http://bit.ly/O0jE79. . Subscribe to i am OTHER on YouTube to stay updated on our releases: http://bit.ly/IAO_subscribe. . Videos, news and more: http://www.iamOTHER.com. Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/iamOTHER. Follow us on Twitter: http://twitter.com/i_am_OTHER. . i am OTHER:. Executive Producer - Pharrell Williams. General Manager - Caron Veazey. Creative Director - Mimi Valdés. Executive Producer - Robin Frank . Associate Producer - Bethany Gould. Assistant Producer - Alexandra DePersia. Digital Marketing - Aviva Yael. . i am OTHER Motion Graphics by Syndrome

@kingofpendragon Most of your post is incoherent and historically inaccurate gibberish. But I will clear up some of the bizarre claims you made anyway just in case anyone else in the thread is interested. The Haiti revolt was much more complicated than your simplistic white versus black analysis. Whites and blacks fought on both sides. The war was a combination of various conflicts. On the side of the slaves, there were huge numbers of Spanish imperialists and French Royalists. Against them there were slave owners and traders, both black and white; along with French Republicans and Spanish troops. The British later also got involved supporting the independence movement. The war also contained several sub-conflicts including a brief civil war between blacks and mullatos. To cast this mess as a simple slave versus owner, o r black versus white struggle says more about how your mind works than it does about the Haiti war. You simply see only what you want to see. You then claim that the main beneficiaries of the Mali slave trade were the French! Really? If that were true do you really think the French would have abolished it? Actually the main beneficiaries of the Mali slave empire were the Mali elites. The French by that time did not own slaves and did not trade in slaves. They did not benefit from t he African slave trade in any way. The African slave trade had been booming long before any Europeans arrived in Africa and long before the Industrial Revolution. Most of the African Kingdoms sold slaves to other African kingdoms or to Arab traders further north. Europeans did not own slaves. Rich Europeans had paid servants instead and those servants were usually other Europeans. It was not British slave traders who first hooked into this trade and took it across the Atlantic as you claimed; it was Portuguese traders followed by Dutch. The British came much later. Just so you know. Even at the height of the Trans-Atlantic slave trade, there were fa r more African slaves owned by other Africans and even more owned by Arabs, than there ever were in the Americas. By the early 1800s, slavery, though never really a feature of European societies anyway, had been abolished by every European country. The United States followed in 1865. From 1865, no European or American power allowed slavery in any of its possessions. But slavery still boomed across Africa and millions of people were still being sold into sla very by African slave kingdoms. The so called 'scramble for Africa' began in 1881, long after slavery had already been abolished across the white world, and as European powers quickly divided up the continent they began to abolish slavery and slave trading wherever they found i t. The African Kingdoms fought hard against this but they were no match for superior European military force. In Mali for example, millions of slaves were freed as the French colonies expanded inland and the slave centres all along the Niger River were shut down. The British did the same in what is now Nigeria and on the Gold coast. The vast majority of North-West Africa, where most American slaves had come from, had been cleared of slavery by the turn of the twentieth century, by the French. Of course the Europeans were not in Africa to help. They were there with the same aims of any empire in history, incl uding the African ones, to plunder resources. They brought their own injustices. But only in Belgian held territory were people no better off under Eur opean than African rule. The atrocities committed by the Belgians were legendary; just as savage as those committed by the Kinlaza and Kimpanzu Kingdoms which had previously ruled the area. In the Congo the arrival of the Belgians was a case of – 'Meet the new boss – same as the old one.' But across most of the rest of Africa the new boss, though exploitative and unjust, was far less so than the barbaric kingdoms which had preceded him: Which is why most African people were quite happy to see those old kingdoms wiped out. But wh at about those African territories which retained some form of nominal independence? Well the people there were not so lucky. The Ethiopian Empire was forced to abolish slavery by Italy in 1902, although the practise remained widespread throughout large parts of it where Italian influence was not strong. Niger gained its independence from France in 1958 and slavery immediately became legal again. Niger did not finally abolish slavery until 2003. Mauritania also reintroduced slavery when the French moved out. Slavery was abolished there again after UN sanctions in 2007. So yes: Europeans engaged in slavery, just not on anything like the same scale as the Africans did. And in the end it was Europeans, not Africans that ended slavery, not Africans. And various forms of slavery still exist in some places, mostly in Africa and the Muslim world even though it is illegal; but it is certainly not tolerated in Europe or North America.

Telling a lit tle black kid that he will end up doing drugs or a little girl that she sucks at sports just because of what they look like is not the same as telling a white boy either of those things, because in the first two cases the message is almost inevitably going to get repeated over and over again in lots of little ways throughout their lives, until they end up believing it.

I don't think we're racist in France (might be a few, but what can we do ?). We believe in integration, meaning that the people coming to live here will be French and slowly merge into our culture and society (while if they want remaining aware of where they're from, and proud if they want to). There is maybe a limit to that : French don't like people that are French on paper, live in France, are born in France but don't feel French. That's the signal that integration didn't work. It's not racism... It's us seeing that integration didn't work. That's also why some Muslims cause issues : they don't want to share our culture and our ideas. A society can only survive if its people share the same interests and ideas (guess why the Roman Empire fell?). France is not like the USA : we don't want to have minorities all over the place, living among themselves. Sadly it happens, because we underestimate the difficulties it is for people to integrate. Turns out education in school is not enough, and especially in banlieues people don't see a lot of French (feeling French) so they can't integrate. The more the reject French cultures and ideas and the more they'll have a hard time with French I guess. It's a complicated issue here, because we want people to feel French while they don't want to integrate (some even start to hate France). Like I said : complex, different from the USA : welcome to Europe. (and now you understand why Germany will have difficulties if they bring 1M Syrians in their country). I'll even say this : far right in France is no t racist. They just want the French culture not to take anything from other cultures, and they want all the people in France to be as French as possible. There is no racism. But they are too stringent on their definition of French, and are home to a lot of racists. If you think about culture and n ot "race" (fuck I don't like to use this word because it make no sense, THERE I S NO RACE, WAKE UP AMERICA) you'll understand why did you see a >black woman from the USA that does not share the Afro-American culture. I think the word we use (cul ture VS race) tells us a lot about our countries ;) And gosh we're bad in English x_x

You can't find any "french-african" in France as we don't say it. We just say "french". We don't call people "immigrants" too. Racist people makes this kind of distinctions here ; others don't and it's very bad considered to call someone a "french-african" or such things instead of a french here. Please consider us as all french, nothing else. And please when you visit us, you could at least learn how to say "bonjour, excusez-moi, parlez-vous anglais ?" (hello, excuse me, do you speak english ?) before starting the conversation. It would take like 2 minuts to learn and would be more respectful. By the way, the drawings on the store means : Hollande : "together for a new world" Obama : "Ok brother" the Maya : "the change is now !" It is both an obvious joke about the "end of the world" theories and a joke about our president campaign. His main sentence while the presidential campaign was "le changement c'est maintenant" (the change is now). It was his favorite sentence, like "yes we can" for your president. It is just a joke about politics and the antic mayan calendar theories. There is absolutely no t racism at all in it, even for your very special victimhood and ethnocentric standards. You see a picture with a black on it, while a normal person wouldn't care about the color of the skin of the protagonists, you are searching for racism, trying to see if ther e is black people in the store, etc. What's wrong with you ? When I see a picture with a white, an asian or an arab I don't understand, I don't searc h for racism in it. At the moment, we can see you HOPE it is racist. That's the problem. Instead of traveling the world in order to find racism, you bring it with you and see it everywhere - and expect to see it. It's not a fair attitude for others you judge too quickly (and believe me, you can't deeply understand a country in a few days asking people on the capital). Your attitude toward this simple picture is very representative of your obsession (because this is what it seems to be : an obsession). You can do more than "being a black man". You can just be a man, travel and enjoy the meetings and the culture. Here, the color of your skin is as important and interesting as the color of your eyes, your hair and your shoes. It would be ridiculous to define yourself by the color of your hair or your shoes, right ? As a french, when I see a man, whatever is color is, obsessed by it and asking about it people on the street, the only thing I think is : how ridiculous. I feel very uncomfortable for you while watching this video.

I have also traveled all around Europe and outside of Germany, I have experienced more racism in the US than anywhere else. I did notice how differently I was treated as an American than my African counterparts in Italy...that was a bit offsetting. I was in Italy for a few years and felt at home. The people were very nice and welcoming to me. But again, I tried to speak as much of the Language as I possibly could at least greetings.  Europeans are very funny about you at least trying to say Hello, Thank you, Please...I am going back to Germany though to see if my experience is any different that it was a few years ago.

replies.commentText: Yes, I think he probably thought the blacks were holding back. Which they may have been, but it was more so out of the fact they probably have seen or felt some racism, but not to the point they felt that they had to be angry or start telling their stories. They were more conservative about over voicing any concerns. The US, it's so divided that we feel it more and it's more in your face. People are angry and to a point deserve to be. People in Europe can discuss these issues without feeling as though they are attacking anyone. I have European friends and American friends. There is racism everywhere. Some advertisements like what we saw in the video are shocking and I will never understand them. But, France has always been an open and accepting country. My friends who ask how I could have lived in Italy, they are racists. I remind them that in the beginning of the Katrina hurricane in New Orleans, Italy was one of the if not the first country to send help. USA was not even close to sending help by the time Italy help arrived. During the 20's and 30's when all hell was breaking out racially in the US, Paris was a safe haven for blacks. Mos t black entertainers retire to France and have renewed careers. Are there racists in  Europe? YES, but the US is just as bad if not worse.
Thanks Alex.

Are there a lot of black People in Germany? Did you feel welcome there? I am asking this question because I have to choose a European language, and go to France or Germany next year for work. I was interested if you felt ok in Germany?

@bamafencer12 
Maybe you don't understand French? So you felt you were treated better??
I do understand French and Spanish fyi..

@Saving/me If he's from the USA, and Black, then he might very well have been treated better in France than in his own country. A number of Black Americans (including an older relative of mine who fought at Normandy) have testified to this over many decades. I try to point out to fello w Black Americans that the situation might be different if they were North Africans, or even francophone Blacks from Mali or the Antilles.        Once on my return from France in the lat 1980s I tried to publish an article on the situation of peoples of color in France with a Black American women's magazine known as ESSENCE. They rejected that article and (I later learned) a similar article b y a Black American. But then they published another article talking about how grand life in France was for Black people. But I noticed that all those prosp erous Black people interviewed who found life so rewarding in Franc e were Black Americans. This prompted me and another brother I'd met over there to pen now angry letters to ESSENCE to set the record straight (as best we could considering we weren't French people of color), and to criticize the magazine for failing in its responsibilities.    I had been reading up on SOS, the National Front, the situation of North Africans and blacks beforehand. And while in France I took some time to talk to Francophone Blacks and North Africans, as well as talking to SOS people, and at least one philosopher connected at that time with LES TEMPS MODERNES. I also visited and spoke with persons connected with PRESENCE AFRICAINES.      So while I was not (and am not) an expert on these matters, I took some effort to try to inform myself rather than simply drawing conclusions based on my personal "experience" as some naively do.   One thing that stuck in my memory was that Francophone Blacks and Arabs seems to react to French police (and police to them) which was eerily like what I've seen here in the USA.     But as for my own experiences in France they were quite benign. Hell, I enjoyed myself! I did feel like the we ight of race was off my shoulders in ways unimaginable in the USA. I could see why an older relative who had fought at Normandy said he was tempted to stay in France and never r eturn t o >Jim Crow America. Except for Frenchmen who dislike Americans, they were generally friendly. I can see how a Black American can get an overly benign picture of France.   No, France does have its pr oblems with racism.  And from what I hear about the popularity of the National Front it could be worse than many imagine. But I've no evidence that France is WORST than others. In both France and the USA, the question is whether the democratic ideals of our two societies will prevail over racism, or whether we shall enter into an era of fascistic oppression, barbarism and misery.
@Wild Wolf I'm glad to hear SOS still exist. How effective is it?

@Tai Cooley You are incorrect when you state that white Americans do not obsess over skin color. Skin color and race are very salient in the U.S., because more often than not, skin color determines one's overall social status/standing. I also think your view of black Americans is very limited. There's certainly a sizable number of low income blacks in the U.S., but mos t black Americans are either working class or middle class (like most Americans in general). If you want to know more abo ut black upper income Americans --read Lawrence Otis Graham's best selling book entitled "Our Kind of People." --------- "Debutante cotillions, Million-dollar homes, Summers in Martha's Vineyard. Membership in the Links, Jack & Jill, Deltas, Boule, and AKAs. An obsession with the right schools, families, social clubs, and skin complexion. This is the world of the black American upper class and the focus of the first book written about the black elite by a member of this hard-to-penetrate group. Author and TV commentator Lawrence Otis Graham, one of the nation's most prominent spokesm en on race and class, spent six years interviewing the weal thiest black families in America. He includes historical photos of a people that made their first millions in the 1870s. Graham tells who's in and who's not in the group today with separate chapters on the elite in New York, Los Angeles, Washington, Chicago, Detroit, Memphis, Atlanta, Philadelphia, Nashville, and New Orleans." ------ Honestly, this will give you the best glimpse into how the black aristocracy in the U.S. think.  In truth, the maj ority of black Americans who are upper income routinely point out that black Americans are mixed and not merely of African ancestry. My family is definitely a mixture of all races , like many black American families; therefore, I agree that it is a complete misno mer to label bla ck Americans "African."

@Summer Sunshine I never thought that there weren't any middle class black Americans. I know that black Americans have the highest GDP compared to other blacks around the world. I have a strong accent and they ask where I am from so I tell them East Africa but live in France. So they automatically ask how do the whites treat me here. I thought to myself "why would you ask me that? You can be asking me so many other or important quest ions." Black Americans are definitely colour struck too. I'm not light skinned as you can see but my hair is pretty fine textured. They ask me if I a m mixed race and which parent is w hite and black. I laughed and said I am not mixed race. I'm originally from Mauritius. Everything seemed t o be about race, but the anglo Americans never onced asked me how do the blacks behave here or questions like that.

@Tai Cooley That's interesting since there were middle class Black Americans even in the 1700s & 1800s. However the black middle classes at least doubled or tripled since the 1960s. But I wonder where you are from if you didn't know that there were middle clas s Black Americans. Even as  a black American schoolboy I knew there were middle class blacks in the West Indies and Africa. I sometimes read W est Indian and African thinkers like CLR James, George Padmore, Eric Williams, Kwame Nkrumah, Amilcar Cabral, Camara Laye, Frantz Fanon, Chinua Achebe, Nelson Mandela and others. In short, I wanted to KNOW and to understand. Hence I inquired, and developed numerous friends among Africans and Caribbean people living in the USA. I can only be curious as to why you're not familiar with some of our thinkers and writers; persons like W.E.B. Du Bois, Anna Julia Cooper, Alain Locke, Richard Wright, Joy James, James Baldwin, Paul Robeson, Langston Hughes, Angela Y. Davis, Michelle Alexander, Manning Marable,  bell hooks, Cornel West and others I could suggest. For if you were so informed it would have been hard for you to have been unaware of the existence of an Ame rican Black middle class. And you'd probably also know how racial caste in America works such that "whiteness" is hegemonic; so much so that in the USA whiteness is taken (prereflectively) as being virtually the norm of all that is right, good, beautiful and even human. Those who are identified with the norm often don't speak it,but rather simply assume it without even thinking about it. Those not identified with the norm, or even deemed the opposite of the norm do not have that privilege.     Most Am erican black people know (or at least sense) that they are the anti-thesis of the norm (even though some of us try even today to assimilate to it).  This is largely why the strug gle for black empowerment and liberation in America has been for more than just certain economic improvements, but rather has been from the very beginning a struggle for our humanity.  I don't expect you to understand this from day one.  But if you choose to speak on it, it would be well if you took some time and effort to inquire and seek to understand.

@SagesseNoir I think it's actually fairly easy for African immigrants to assume that most black Americans are poor, because more often than not , African immigrants are not wealthy, and are therefore relegated to the worst communities in America, upon arriving. This means that much of their early socialization is with t he black underclass. Very rarely would an Afri >can immigrant move to rural parts of America (therefore, they are not really exposed to the white underclass). And those without money are certainly not exposed t o the black middle class, because it takes money to afford to purchase a home in a good/middle class community.

@Summer Sunshine If Africans come here as common laborers, then they may be exposed mainly to the Black poor. However, many come here as students; and regardless of whether they attend an HBCU or a predominantly white university, they're bound to meet middle clas s African Americans. Also, come Africans are so ensconced in white communities as to have little contact with American Blacks.   But if there are American Blacks in those almost lily white communities they are probably middle class people themselves. The Africans who attended this private mostly white university in which I did graduate work would have met mostly whites, but the blacks whom they et were nearly completely middle class. Those who attended my HBCU undergraduate school would have met a mixture of middle class and poorer American Blacks. (Needless to say, al their professors would be middle class people). A lot does depend on where you live, work and go to school. But I do recall that while growing up in the inner city of Baltimore I rarely met Africans. I began to meet significant numbers of Africans only once I was at the university, an institution which is  geared toward studies which help to either maintain one's middle class status if you have it, or if you don't (as in my case) to enable you to attain the middle class condition. While I don't have scientific data on this as of yet, it appears to me that in America, unlike Europe where so many Africans live as common laborers, Africans tend to come with at least a modicum to middle class background when they arrive in the USA.

commentThread.commentText: There are so many more similarities between black people all over the world than there are differences. replies.commentText: In ANGELA DAVIS: AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY, the famous 1960s revolutionary mentioned troubles she had in France, as a light skinned African American, whom the French sometimes mistook for an Algerian. But when they knew she was American, French conduct changed. I notice as a Black American (and dark skinned) that I had little trouble with the French when I traveled there in the 1980s & 90s as long as they  knew I was American. Francophone Blacks and (especially) North Africans experienced (at least so many told me) a seamier side of French life.
Still I think it's worth going. I would recommend you go to France if you can. French racists do not represent all of France, though the rise of the National Front is bothersome.
While I can't be certain of it, I doubt that France has the same scale of anti-Black racist violence as we have in the USA--as we've always had in the USA. But it does exist.
Thank you very much for your information!

@Elizabeth Gonzalez The problem of racism in France is REAL. I hear Francopone Blacks here in the USA talk about it all the time. French speaking Black writers from the time of Cesaire and Fanon have been examining and making critiques of Frenc h racis m. Black people whom I met in France during the late 1980s & early 90s talked to me about this problem. So did North Africans. Angela Y. Davis, who hailed from Bull Connor's Birmingham, AL, describes her own experiences of this while she was a student in Paris. I PERSONALLY SAW police harassing North Africans and Blacks while there. Now I think the yo ung Black American ought to be less comic in his approach, more "professional" in his inquiries regarding Fr ench racism. But to dismiss his inquiries as stupid would be itself a stupid dismissal. Have you guys even heard about the NATIONAL FRONT and their reco rd of racist violence? This is REAL. And what has the speaker's light complexion has to do with this? Would it make any difference if he were the complexion of Michelle Obama?

@MSMikado8 That has been an issue in my country (USA) since the time of slavery. The light skin/dark skin divide was actually created by the white slaveholders, and continued for at least a century after slavery by certain practices of discrimination. My mother, a light skinned woman from the Jim Cr ow> South, noted even after moving North that often the few "better" jobs available to Blacks were often advertised specifically for LIGHT SKINNE D "colored" perso n ("colored" and "Negro" being more common names for American blacks in the 1950s & early 60s). In a book called the COLOR COMPLEX, it was noticed that given the small privileges afforded to lighter skinned American Blacks it was generally the case that most better educated and we ll off Black were light skinned. That is less true today than decades ago, but has not completely  disappeared. What's harmful to Blacks is the extent to which Blacks--light , dark and in-between--have internalized the psychology of this "colorism" (as it's sometimes called in the USA). It is emotionally harmful even if it doesn't divide politically the A merican Black population as it has t he South African Blacks from the "coloreds". Basically, the light skin/dark skinned divide--whereby value and beauty are increased the closer one is to white, and diminished the further one is from whiteness (or closer to blackness)--is really an internalization w ithin the Black psych e of white racism and Eurocentric aesthetics and values. This sickness was diminished but not e nded by the Black consciousness movement during the 1960s in the USA.

@Peacewithchildren What I'm talking about may be more common among Francophone Blacks from the West Indies. The experience of Blacks from Martinique, to take one example, is in a sense similar to that of Blacks of the USA. They, like we, are descendants of Africans deported during the slave trade. And what we sometimes call "colorism" in the USA, began in the French Caribbean (like in the USA) during slavery. That divide was imposed by the whites. However, while the French (at least after slavery) offered the carrot of assimilation, in the USA segregation was the standard policy--and remains a FACT (no longer the law) even today in the USA. Colorism may have been intensified in the French territories because the ideology of assimilation promised you could gain equality, escape racial inferiority by assimilating French values, language, etc. In short, by becoming white. The mentally colonized Black American often also wanted to be assimilated, to become white, but was made to know in no uncertain terms that he was not welcome--not even with a Harvard U Ph.D. and mastery of the King's English and a dozen other European languages.  Largely for this reason a Black person as "color struck" as martiniique's Mayotte Capecia (as is evident in her work "Je suis Martiniquaise) would be unusual in the USA. The very bluntness of Americ an racism compared to a more nuanced and subtle Fre nch racism would likely jolt an Amer ican Black back into consciousness. Perhaps that's why our Harlem Renaissance preceded  Francophone Negritude.      In Africa, I'm not as sure. French colonialism did seduce Africans with the policy and ideology of assimilationism, But unlike both the Martiniquais and Les Americains Noires , the African is not uprooted from his/her land and cu lture. Mental colonialism (of which colorism is one feature) may not be as deeply rooted in as many people as in the French Caribbean. But I'm pretty sure that it existed because I' ve read African writers who talk about it. But it may have affected ma inly the African elites, and less so the masses. And the condition may not run as deep.

@Jocelyne_Alexandra Did you say that mixed marriages were at the rate of 20% in France? Is the non-indigenous part of the French population actually large enough for that to happen?

@Jocelyne_Alexandra I must admit that my own impressions may be dated because I've not been back to France Since the 1990s. I enjoyed my stay there. But I was concerned when I heard Blacks and North Africans complaining about racism. In the 1980s when I was a student, Blacks here in the States had become aroused by the fight against apartheid in South Africa, and then word had gotten back to some of us about the National Front. Some Black American newspapers and magazines asked me to inquire to see what I might find. I must admit that I felt the burden o f race far less in France than in the USA.  And I h ad elder relatives who fought in WWII, one at Normandy, and who thought that France was almost paradise compared to our KKK-ridden and segregation bound society. (Richard Wright once said that there was more freedom in one block of Paris than in the whole of the USA).  But talking to Tunisians, Malians, Martiniquais and others gave me a different and more sobering picture. I couldn't help noticing that many white French who were friendly to me were quite unfriendly and even hostile to francophone Blacks. Yet I didn't see the marks of segregation so commonplace in the USA that we Americans have ceased noticing it here. I also saw a degree of social mingling between Blacks and whites in Paris that exceeded even what one would find at that time in the largest and most liberal of American cities. And then there was the anti-racist group called SOS and their inscriptions "touche pas mon copain." That, at least, was encouraging.  As I was telling a friend recently visiting from Paris "At least your country doesn't have an INGRAINED tradition of racial caste and segregation that we have in the USA, and which even the Movements of the 1960s couldn't fully dislodge. If you are determined to end racism in France you may find it much easier than we will in the USA."
